tasks.title: Initialize CDK Project Structure
tasks.description: Set up the AWS CDK project structure with TypeScript, including the repository organization and basic configuration.
tasks.details:
1. Create a new directory for the project
2. Initialize CDK project: `npx aws-cdk init app --language typescript`
3. Set up the repository structure according to PRD:
   - `/lib` for CDK infrastructure code
   - `/frontend` for React application
   - `/lambda` for backend Lambda functions
   - `/bin` for CDK app entry point
   - `/.taskmaster` for task management
4. Configure TypeScript settings in `tsconfig.json`
5. Set up `.gitignore` file with appropriate entries for CDK and React
6. Initialize npm workspace in root directory
7. Create README.md with project overview
tasks.testStrategy: Verify project structure matches requirements. Run `npm run build` to ensure TypeScript compilation works. Validate CDK synthesis with `cdk synth` to confirm no errors in the basic setup.

tasks.title: Implement S3 Static Website Hosting
tasks.description: Create the CDK infrastructure for S3 bucket configuration to host the React application's static files.
tasks.details:
1. Create a new CDK construct for S3 bucket in `/lib`
2. Configure the bucket for static website hosting:
   ```typescript
   const websiteBucket = new s3.Bucket(this, 'WeddingWebsiteBucket', {
     websiteIndexDocument: 'index.html',
     websiteErrorDocument: 'index.html', // SPA fallback
     publicReadAccess: true,
     removalPolicy: cdk.RemovalPolicy.DESTROY, // For development only
     autoDeleteObjects: true, // For development only
   });
   ```
3. Add bucket policy to allow public read access
4. Export the bucket name as a CloudFormation output
5. Implement deployment mechanism for React build artifacts to S3
6. Add bucket lifecycle rules for optimal performance
tasks.testStrategy: Run `cdk synth` to verify CloudFormation template generation. Deploy stack with `cdk deploy` and verify bucket creation in AWS console. Test bucket configuration by uploading a simple HTML file and accessing it via the website endpoint.

subtasks.title: Implement Bucket Lifecycle Rules

Also add rules for cleaning up incomplete multipart uploads after 7 days to avoid unnecessary storage costs.

tasks.title: Setup CI/CD Pipeline for Frontend Deployment
tasks.description: Implement a CI/CD pipeline to automatically build and deploy the React application to S3 when changes are pushed.
tasks.details:
1. Create a basic CI/CD configuration using GitHub Actions or AWS CodePipeline
2. For GitHub Actions, create `.github/workflows/deploy.yml`:
   ```yaml
   name: Deploy Wedding Website
   on:
     push:
       branches: [main]
   jobs:
     build-and-deploy:
       runs-on: ubuntu-latest
       steps:
         - uses: actions/checkout@v3
         - uses: actions/setup-node@v3
           with:
             node-version: 16
         - name: Install dependencies
           run: cd frontend && npm ci
         - name: Build React app
           run: cd frontend && npm run build
         - name: Configure AWS credentials
           uses: aws-actions/configure-aws-credentials@v1
           with:
             aws-access-key-id: ${{ secrets.AWS_ACCESS_KEY_ID }}
             aws-secret-access-key: ${{ secrets.AWS_SECRET_ACCESS_KEY }}
             aws-region: us-east-1
         - name: Deploy to S3
           run: aws s3 sync frontend/build/ s3://${BUCKET_NAME} --delete
         - name: Invalidate CloudFront
           run: aws cloudfront create-invalidation --distribution-id ${DISTRIBUTION_ID} --paths "/*"
   ```
3. Set up necessary environment variables and secrets
4. Configure deployment to only run on main branch changes
5. Add caching for node_modules to speed up builds
tasks.testStrategy: Test the CI/CD pipeline by making a small change to the frontend code and pushing to the repository. Verify that the pipeline runs successfully and deploys the changes to S3. Check that CloudFront invalidation works by verifying the updated content is available through the CloudFront URL.

subtasks.title: Create GitHub Actions Workflow File
subtasks.description: Set up the basic GitHub Actions workflow file structure for the CI/CD pipeline that will build and deploy the React application to AWS S3.
subtasks.details:
1. Create the directory structure `.github/workflows/` in the project root
2. Create a new file `deploy.yml` in this directory
3. Add the basic workflow configuration:
   - Set name to 'Deploy Wedding Website'
   - Configure to trigger on push to main branch
   - Create a single job named 'build-and-deploy'
   - Set it to run on ubuntu-latest
   - Add checkout step using actions/checkout@v3
   - Add Node.js setup using actions/setup-node@v3 with node-version: 16
subtasks.testStrategy: Verify the workflow file syntax using GitHub Actions linting tools. Push a small change to a test branch and set up a temporary workflow to validate the basic structure works without performing actual deployment.

subtasks.title: Configure Build and Test Steps
subtasks.description: Add the build and test steps to the GitHub Actions workflow to prepare the React application for deployment.
subtasks.details:
1. Add the following steps to the workflow after the Node.js setup:
   - Add a step to install dependencies: `run: cd frontend && npm ci`
   - Add a step to run tests: `run: cd frontend && npm test -- --passWithNoTests`
   - Add a step to build the React app: `run: cd frontend && npm run build`
2. Implement caching for node_modules to speed up builds:
   ```yaml
   - name: Cache node modules
     uses: actions/cache@v3
     with:
       path: frontend/node_modules
       key: ${{ runner.os }}-node-${{ hashFiles('frontend/package-lock.json') }}
       restore-keys: |
         ${{ runner.os }}-node-
   ```
3. Place this cache step before the dependency installation step
subtasks.testStrategy: Run the workflow in a test environment to verify that dependencies install correctly, tests run, and the build process completes successfully. Check that the cache is being utilized in subsequent runs by examining the workflow logs.

subtasks.title: Set Up AWS Credentials and Secrets
subtasks.description: Configure the GitHub repository with the necessary AWS credentials and secrets to allow the workflow to deploy to S3 and invalidate CloudFront.
subtasks.details:
1. In the GitHub repository settings, navigate to Secrets and Variables > Actions
2. Add the following repository secrets:
   - AWS_ACCESS_KEY_ID: The AWS access key with permissions for S3 and CloudFront
   - AWS_SECRET_ACCESS_KEY: The corresponding secret key
   - BUCKET_NAME: The name of the S3 bucket for deployment
   - DISTRIBUTION_ID: The CloudFront distribution ID
3. Ensure the AWS IAM user has the following permissions:
   - s3:PutObject
   - s3:GetObject
   - s3:ListBucket
   - s3:DeleteObject
   - cloudfront:CreateInvalidation
subtasks.testStrategy: Verify the secrets are properly set in GitHub by checking the repository settings. Test the AWS credentials by running a minimal workflow that only authenticates with AWS and lists S3 buckets to confirm permissions are correct.

subtasks.title: Implement S3 Deployment Step
subtasks.description: Add the deployment step to the GitHub Actions workflow to sync the built React application to the S3 bucket.
subtasks.details:
1. Add the AWS credentials configuration step to the workflow:
   ```yaml
   - name: Configure AWS credentials
     uses: aws-actions/configure-aws-credentials@v1
     with:
       aws-access-key-id: ${{ secrets.AWS_ACCESS_KEY_ID }}
       aws-secret-access-key: ${{ secrets.AWS_SECRET_ACCESS_KEY }}
       aws-region: us-east-1
   ```
2. Add the S3 deployment step:
   ```yaml
   - name: Deploy to S3
     run: aws s3 sync frontend/build/ s3://${{ secrets.BUCKET_NAME }} --delete
   ```
3. Ensure the `--delete` flag is included to remove old files from the bucket
subtasks.testStrategy: Test the deployment by making a small change to the frontend code, pushing to the main branch, and verifying that the files are correctly uploaded to the S3 bucket. Check that old files are properly removed with the --delete flag.

subtasks.title: Add CloudFront Invalidation Step
subtasks.description: Configure the workflow to invalidate the CloudFront cache after deployment to ensure visitors see the latest version of the website.
subtasks.details:
1. Add the CloudFront invalidation step after the S3 deployment:
   ```yaml
   - name: Invalidate CloudFront
     run: aws cloudfront create-invalidation --distribution-id ${{ secrets.DISTRIBUTION_ID }} --paths "/*"
   ```
2. This command invalidates all paths in the distribution to ensure all updated content is served fresh
3. Verify that the AWS credentials used have the cloudfront:CreateInvalidation permission
subtasks.testStrategy: After a successful deployment, check the CloudFront invalidation status in the AWS Console. Visit the CloudFront URL and verify that the new content is being served. Check browser caching headers to confirm cache invalidation is working properly.

subtasks.title: Implement Deployment Notifications and Error Handling
subtasks.description: Enhance the workflow with notifications for successful and failed deployments, and add error handling to improve pipeline reliability.
subtasks.details:
1. Add a notification step for deployment status using GitHub Actions Slack integration:
   ```yaml
   - name: Notify Slack on success
     if: success()
     uses: rtCamp/action-slack-notify@v2
     env:
       SLACK_WEBHOOK: ${{ secrets.SLACK_WEBHOOK }}
       SLACK_CHANNEL: deployments
       SLACK_TITLE: 'Successful Deployment üöÄ'
       SLACK_MESSAGE: 'Wedding website deployed successfully!'
       SLACK_COLOR: good
   
   - name: Notify Slack on failure
     if: failure()
     uses: rtCamp/action-slack-notify@v2
     env:
       SLACK_WEBHOOK: ${{ secrets.SLACK_WEBHOOK }}
       SLACK_CHANNEL: deployments
       SLACK_TITLE: 'Failed Deployment ‚ùå'
       SLACK_MESSAGE: 'Wedding website deployment failed!'
       SLACK_COLOR: danger
   ```
2. Add error handling for the build process:
   ```yaml
   - name: Build React app
     id: build
     continue-on-error: true
     run: cd frontend && npm run build
   
   - name: Check build status
     if: steps.build.outcome == 'failure'
     run: |
       echo "Build failed, aborting deployment"
       exit 1
   ```
3. Add a step to store build artifacts for debugging:
   ```yaml
   - name: Upload build artifacts
     if: always()
     uses: actions/upload-artifact@v3
     with:
       name: build-artifacts
       path: frontend/build/
       retention-days: 5
   ```
subtasks.testStrategy: Test the error handling by intentionally introducing a build error and verifying that the workflow fails gracefully with appropriate notifications. Test the notification system by completing a successful deployment and checking that the notification is sent correctly. Verify that build artifacts are properly stored for both successful and failed builds.

tasks.title: Create DynamoDB Table for RSVP Data
tasks.description: Implement the DynamoDB table to store RSVP responses from wedding guests.
tasks.details:
1. Add DynamoDB table to the CDK stack in `/lib`:
   ```typescript
   const rsvpTable = new dynamodb.Table(this, 'RSVPTable', {
     partitionKey: { name: 'id', type: dynamodb.AttributeType.STRING },
     billingMode: dynamodb.BillingMode.PAY_PER_REQUEST,
     removalPolicy: cdk.RemovalPolicy.RETAIN, // Protect RSVP data
   });
   
   // Add GSI for querying by email
   rsvpTable.addGlobalSecondaryIndex({
     indexName: 'email-index',
     partitionKey: { name: 'email', type: dynamodb.AttributeType.STRING },
   });
   ```

2. Define the RSVP data model with the following attributes:
   - id: UUID for each RSVP submission
   - name: Guest name
   - email: Guest email address
   - attending: Boolean indicating attendance
   - guestCount: Number of guests in party
   - mealPreferences: Array of meal choices
   - dietaryRestrictions: Special dietary needs
   - comments: Additional information
   - submittedAt: Timestamp

3. Export the table name as a CloudFormation output
4. Add appropriate IAM permissions for Lambda functions to access the table
5. Implement table backup strategy
tasks.testStrategy: Verify DynamoDB table creation in the synthesized CloudFormation template. After deployment, use AWS Console to confirm table structure matches requirements. Test table access with AWS CLI commands. Verify GSI creation and query capability.

tasks.title: Introduce Justfile for Common CDK and Build Commands
tasks.description: Create a justfile with common CDK commands like deploy, diff, synth, and destroy, plus other build commands to streamline development workflow.
tasks.details:
1. Create a `justfile` in the project root:
```justfile
# CDK commands
deploy:
    cdk deploy --require-approval never

deploy-with-approval:
    cdk deploy

diff:
    cdk diff

synth:
    cdk synth

destroy:
    cdk destroy

bootstrap:
    cdk bootstrap

# Build and test commands
build:
    npm run build

test:
    npm test

lint:
    npm run lint

test-watch:
    npm run test -- --watch

# Utility commands
clean:
    rm -rf node_modules dist cdk.out
    npm install

logs stack-name:
    aws logs tail /aws/lambda/{{stack-name}} --follow

# Local development
local:
    sam local start-api

# Help
help:
    @just --list
```

2. Add justfile to .gitignore exceptions if needed

3. Document usage in README.md with common command examples

4. Consider adding environment-specific targets (dev, staging, prod) if multiple environments are used
tasks.testStrategy: Verify justfile syntax by running `just --list` to show available commands. Test each command individually to ensure they execute correctly. Verify CDK commands work with the existing stack configuration. Test build and test commands execute successfully. Document any prerequisites like having `just` command runner installed.

tasks.title: Introduce Prettier and TSLint Standards
tasks.description: Set up code formatting and linting standards using Prettier for consistent code formatting and TSLint for TypeScript code quality enforcement across the project.
tasks.details:
1. Install Prettier and TSLint dependencies:
```bash
npm install --save-dev prettier tslint tslint-config-prettier @typescript-eslint/eslint-plugin @typescript-eslint/parser
```

2. Create .prettierrc configuration file:
```json
{
  "semi": true,
  "trailingComma": "es5",
  "singleQuote": true,
  "printWidth": 80,
  "tabWidth": 2,
  "useTabs": false
}
```

3. Create .prettierignore file:
```
node_modules/
dist/
build/
cdk.out/
*.min.js
*.min.css
```

4. Create tslint.json configuration:
```json
{
  "extends": ["tslint:recommended", "tslint-config-prettier"],
  "rules": {
    "no-console": false,
    "object-literal-sort-keys": false,
    "ordered-imports": false,
    "quotemark": [true, "single"],
    "semicolon": [true, "always"]
  },
  "linterOptions": {
    "exclude": ["node_modules/**", "dist/**", "build/**", "cdk.out/**"]
  }
}
```

5. Add scripts to package.json:
```json
{
  "scripts": {
    "format": "prettier --write \"src/**/*.{ts,tsx,js,jsx,json,css,md}\"",
    "format:check": "prettier --check \"src/**/*.{ts,tsx,js,jsx,json,css,md}\"",
    "lint": "tslint -p tsconfig.json",
    "lint:fix": "tslint -p tsconfig.json --fix"
  }
}
```

6. Set up pre-commit hooks with husky (optional):
```bash
npm install --save-dev husky lint-staged
```

7. Add lint-staged configuration to package.json:
```json
{
  "lint-staged": {
    "*.{ts,tsx}": ["tslint --fix", "prettier --write"],
    "*.{js,jsx,json,css,md}": ["prettier --write"]
  }
}
```

8. Format all existing code:
```bash
npm run format
npm run lint:fix
```
tasks.testStrategy: Verify Prettier installation by running `prettier --version`. Test Prettier formatting by running `npm run format` and checking that code is consistently formatted. Verify TSLint installation by running `tslint --version`. Test linting by running `npm run lint` and ensuring it catches style violations. Create intentionally poorly formatted test files and verify they are corrected by the format and lint scripts. Test that the justfile commands work with the new lint script. Verify that existing CDK TypeScript code passes linting rules without errors.

tasks.title: Fix Failing npm run build
tasks.description: Diagnose and resolve all issues causing the npm run build command to fail, ensuring successful TypeScript compilation and project build process.
tasks.details:
1. Run `npm run build` to identify specific build failures and error messages
2. Check TypeScript configuration in tsconfig.json for any misconfigurations or missing settings
3. Resolve TypeScript compilation errors:
   - Fix type errors in source files
   - Add missing type declarations
   - Resolve import/export issues
   - Update deprecated TypeScript syntax
4. Verify all dependencies are properly installed by running `npm install`
5. Check for missing or outdated build dependencies in package.json
6. Resolve any ESLint/TSLint errors that block the build process
7. Fix any path resolution issues or missing files
8. Ensure all imported modules and assets exist and are accessible
9. Verify build scripts in package.json are correctly configured
10. Test the build process in both development and production modes
11. Update any build configuration files (webpack.config.js, etc.) if needed
12. Document any configuration changes made during the fix
tasks.testStrategy: Run `npm run build` multiple times to ensure consistent success. Verify that the build output directory contains all expected files. Test the built application by serving it locally and checking functionality. Run the build process on a clean environment (fresh npm install) to verify reproducibility. Check build performance metrics and compare with previous successful builds. Verify that no console errors or warnings appear during the build process.

tasks.title: Integrate Route 53 DNS Configuration for Domain Management
tasks.description: Update the CDK stack to support existing Route 53 public hosted zone for website hosting and create configuration mechanism for providing domain values.
tasks.testStrategy: Verify DNS configuration loads correctly from config file. Test stack deployment with and without DNS config provided. Confirm Route 53 hosted zone is properly imported using the provided zone ID. Verify SSL certificate is correctly associated with CloudFront distribution. Test domain resolution by checking A record points to correct CloudFront distribution. Validate HTTPS redirection works properly. Test deployment across different environments with different domain configurations.

tasks.title: Add S3 access logging to website bucket
tasks.description: Implement access logging for the main website S3 bucket to provide audit trails and meet CDK Nag rule AwsSolutions-S1
tasks.details:
Add S3 access logging to the website bucket in website-bucket.ts:
1. Create a dedicated S3 bucket for website access logs
2. Configure the website bucket to write access logs to the logging bucket
3. Set appropriate lifecycle rules on the logging bucket (90-day retention)
4. Ensure logging bucket has proper permissions and encryption
5. Add CloudFormation output for the logging bucket name
tasks.testStrategy: Verify that access logging is enabled in the synthesized CloudFormation template. Deploy to development environment and confirm log files are being created in the logging bucket. Check that CDK Nag rule AwsSolutions-S1 no longer triggers warnings.

tasks.title: Implement CloudFront geo restrictions configuration
tasks.description: Add configurable geo restrictions to CloudFront distribution to allow content access control by geographic location
tasks.details:
Enhance CloudFront distribution with configurable geo restrictions:
1. Add geo restriction configuration to config/dns.json for each environment
2. Update DnsConfig interface to include optional geoRestrictions settings
3. Pass geo restriction settings from stack to CloudFrontDistribution construct
4. Implement logic to apply geo restrictions only when explicitly configured
5. Document the configuration options in DNS_CONFIGURATION.md
6. Add example configurations for common scenarios (US-only, exclude specific countries)
tasks.testStrategy: Test with different geo restriction configurations in development environment. Verify that CloudFormation correctly applies geo restrictions when configured. Test that distribution works without geo restrictions when not configured. Validate using VPN to test access from restricted locations.

tasks.title: Add deployment region validation for ACM certificates
tasks.description: Implement validation to ensure stack is deployed in us-east-1 when using custom domains with ACM certificates
tasks.details:
Add region validation for ACM certificate requirements:
1. In bin/wedding-website-cdk.ts, add validation when dnsConfig is present
2. Check that CDK_DEFAULT_REGION or configured region is 'us-east-1'
3. If not us-east-1 and custom domain is configured, throw informative error
4. Add clear error message explaining CloudFront certificate requirements
5. Update README with deployment region requirements
6. Consider adding a flag to override validation for advanced users
tasks.testStrategy: Test deployment with custom domain from different regions. Verify error message is clear and helpful when deployed from wrong region. Confirm deployment succeeds from us-east-1. Test that deployments without custom domain work from any region.

tasks.title: Create pre-deployment validation script
tasks.description: Develop a validation script that checks all prerequisites before CDK deployment to prevent common deployment failures
tasks.details:
Create a comprehensive pre-deployment validation script:
1. Create scripts/validate-deployment.ts script
2. Check AWS credentials are configured
3. Verify AWS account has necessary permissions
4. For production deployment with custom domain:
   - Validate Route53 hosted zone exists and is accessible
   - Check domain nameservers point to Route53
   - Verify region is us-east-1 for ACM certificates
5. Check Node.js and CDK CLI versions meet requirements
6. Validate config/dns.json structure if it exists
7. Run cdk synth and check for errors
8. Add npm script 'validate' to package.json
9. Update deployment documentation to include validation step
tasks.testStrategy: Run validation script with various configurations (missing credentials, wrong region, invalid config files). Verify script catches common issues and provides helpful error messages. Test that successful validation correlates with successful deployment.

tasks.title: Add CDK Nag security scanning to the stack
tasks.description: Integrate CDK Nag into the CDK application to automatically check for security best practices and compliance
tasks.details:
Implement CDK Nag security scanning:
1. Install cdk-nag package: npm install --save-dev cdk-nag
2. In bin/wedding-website-cdk.ts, import and apply AwsSolutionsChecks
3. Configure CDK Nag to run only in non-production or with explicit flag
4. Add suppressions for acceptable warnings with justifications:
   - S1: Website bucket access logging (if not implemented)
   - CFR1: Geo restrictions (if intentionally disabled)
5. Create config/cdk-nag-suppressions.json for centralized suppression management
6. Add npm script 'security-check' to run cdk synth with CDK Nag enabled
7. Document all suppressions with business justifications
8. Add CDK Nag check to CI/CD pipeline
tasks.testStrategy: Run cdk synth with CDK Nag enabled and verify it identifies expected issues. Confirm suppressions work correctly with proper justifications. Test that CDK Nag doesn't block development deployments but does run in security check mode.
